metadata.title: Thinking Outside the Box — Non-Classical Solutions to Classic Math Riddles

Arts, Culture, & Mathematics

Thinking Outside the Box — Non-Classical Solutions to Classic Math Riddles

Let's find loopholes in riddles!

Lizka, 2nd week

ACADEMICS LOUNGE. Wednesday’s Dumb Solutions to Classic Math Riddles event generated a number of novel approaches to age-old problems. Let’s take a look. “Official” answers are not listed in order to avoid spoilers.

Riddle 1. A jar is standing on a table in such a way that half of it is hanging in the air, and half is on the table. In 30 minutes, the jar falls off. Why?

Solutions offered.

The table is made up of a weak material. As time passes, the jar sinks into— and eventually through— the table.

Maybe there was an earthquake.

A mouse was in the bottom of the jar, and finally moved to the other side after 30 minutes. The jar (and the mouse in it) fell.

There was water in the jar. The moon creates tides, and when the tide shifted, the jar tipped over.


Riddle 2. A child falls out of the window of an 11-storey building and is completely unhurt. How?


Solutions offered.

The child can fly (for instance, it might be a bird).

The child was testing a parachute.

Kids can’t count. There were not 11 storeys in that building.

The child could be a cat.

Someone caught the child out of the window below.

The child was Tom Cruise.

There are 11 storeys, but 11 is in binary. Also, there was a conveniently placed trampoline.


Riddle 3. Once upon a time a farmer went to a market and purchased a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage. On his way home, the farmer came to the bank of a river and rented a boat. But crossing the river by boat, the farmer could carry only himself and a single one of his purchases: the wolf, the goat, or the cabbage. If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, or the goat would eat the cabbage. The farmer's challenge was to carry himself and his purchases to the far bank of the river, leaving each purchase intact. How did he do it?


Solutions offered.

The farmer is really good at throwing.

The farmer has a cannon, or trebuchet, or a hot air balloon.

The world is a Möbius strip.

The farmer can get a bigger boat.

The river is frozen.

What does “intact” mean, really? If the goat swallows the cabbage whole, is it intact?

We could teach the goat or the wolf to power the boat...


Riddle 4. Four people come to a river in the night. There is a narrow bridge, but it can only hold two people at a time. They have one torch and, because it's night, the torch has to be used when crossing the bridge. Person A can cross the bridge in 1 minute, B in 2 minutes, C in 5 minutes, and D in 8 minutes. When two people cross the bridge together, they must move at the slower person's pace. The question is, can they all get across the bridge if the torch lasts only 15 minutes?


Solutions offered.

They could set an unimportant part of the bridge on fire. (E.g. the railings.)

Piggy-back rides.

You could probably throw the torch...

Yes. They can wait until the morning.


Riddle 5. I'm going to give you one, two, or three dollars in response to a statement you make. If your statement is false, I'll give you one dollar. If your statement is true, I'll give you two or three dollars. Can you find a statement that guarantees you will receive three dollars?


Solutions offered.

“This is a robbery, give me $3, or else...”

Get $3 from someone else.

Confuse them into cooperation, say something that is neither true or false, or say something that is both true and false, and watch them flounder. Inevitably, they will need to give you $3.

Interpret “dollars” in terms of another currency. Pesos use “$,” don’t they?


Riddle 6. Two people walked up to a river. They need to cross it, but there is no bridge and neither of them can swim. On the riverbank there is a boat that can hold only one person. Both travelers managed to cross the river without getting wet. How?


Solutions offered.

The boat is magical or automated.

The people can fly, or are really good at jumping.

The river is a deity— to cross it means to make it mad.

Water is not wet.

“You know how ducks have this coating...”

They could force fire ants to make a bridge...


Riddle 7. There were six peaches in a bag. Ms. Honey gave each of her six students one of these peaches, and when she was done, one peach remained in the bag. How was this possible?


Solutions offered.

The bag has a false bottom; in reality, there were 7 peaches.

Every time Ms. Honey gave a student a peach, they gave her a peach. She ate five.

One of the peaches was cloned via Banach-Tarski (or your preferred cloning method).

A long time passed between the first and last peach, and a tree had managed to grow and come to fruition in that time.


Riddle 8. Three cows are standing in a field. They are standing in a straight line, head-to-tail, so that they are all facing the same direction. The cow in the back says, “I can see a cow in front of me.” The cow in the middle says, “I can see a cow in front of me.” The cow in the front says, “I can see a cow in front of me.” How can this be?


Solutions offered.

There was a mirror in front of the front cow.

A person whose name is “Ack Ow” is standing in front of the front cow.

There was actually a fourth (or zeroeth) cow in front of the front cow. It would then be true that there are three cows. But there wouldn’t be only three cows.

The Earth is the field. (See diagram.)
